chapter.title: Children of Noah
chapter.subtitle: בני נח - Bnei Noach
chapter.para: Bnei Noach are the children of Noah. haShem Elokim commanded all bnei Noach to keep the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach. The rainbow is a sign of that covenant. It's an eternal covenant. As long as a society keeps to the covenant, haShem Elokim will not destroy that society.

All of humanity are bnei Noach. Bnei Yisrael has a distinction from the merit of Avraham and are not classified as bnei Noach even though technically they are also descended from Noah.
Nedarim 31a

Therefore, whenever the term bnei Noach is used, this is referring those that are not bnei Yisrael. I currently do not know if gerim are bnei Noach. Gerim are attached to bnei Yisrael and are described as being part of klal Yisrael. It appears to me that gerim would then also be from the merit of Avraham and set apart with with bnei Yisrael.

Bnei Noach may give the holiest of offerings; the burnt offering. The burnt offering is the only offering they may give as bnei Noach proper. It appears to me, that this is because once bnei Noach give a proper burnt offering, they enter a new status as a ger, which is someone who is now sojourning into a relationship with haShem.

Bnei Noach may or may not emanate from klipot nogah. If bnei Noach keep the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach for any other reason than for the sake of heaven, they emanate not from klipot nogah, but rather from the three impure klipot where no good exists. They then do not receive a portion in Olam haBah. However, if bnei Noach keep the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach for the sake of Heaven, they emanate from klipot nogah where there is good and evil. They do receive a portion in Olam haBa. One must be attached to the Source of Olam haBa.

Bnei Noach are made in the image of haShem Elokim:Tosephos YomTov on Avos 3:14 in explanation of the saying of Rabbi Akiva in the Mishna there "beloved is Man who is created in the Divine Image" as this was also said with reference to Bnai Noach - and according to what the Rambam writes in the Laws of Kings. See there.
